keywords: process for managing unpaid leave salary adjustments
navigation_hints: Process for managing unpaid leave salary adjustments

cognitive_walkthrough.goal: Find and validate Daily Wage Calculator feature

exploration_path.hint: Process for managing unpaid leave salary adjustments

exploration_path.reason: Appears to be a workflow step, not a navigation element

page_analysis.title: Bayzat
headings: Daily Wage CalculationSet the daily rate calculation for employee's salary
Payroll TemplatesCreate, view and customize templates
Employee Loan PoliciesConfigure loan policies that employees can apply for
Leave salary policyThis policy outlines the criteria for applying for leave salary
Leave encashment policyNewThis policy outlines the criteria for applying for leave encashmentLearn m

evidence.breadcrumb: Unpaid Leave Request > Approval > Payroll Deduction Calculation
evidence.reason: Breadcrumb matches business workflow pattern (not a menu path)
evidence.note: This describes a business process workflow, not a clickable navigation path. Conceptual flows are documented for understanding the feature, not for UI navigation.

evidence.caveat: Navigation paths are from Zendesk docs (guidance only). Actual UI may differ.
Navigation paths are from Zendesk docs (guidance only). Actual UI may differ.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Daily pay is calculated by dividing total salary by the number of actual working days, excluding public holidays

checks.name: semantic_daily_pay_calculation_accuracy
checks.claim_text: Daily pay is calculated by dividing total salary by the number of actual working days, excluding public holidays
checks.validation_hint: Verify calculation matches: Salary / (Total Working Days - Public Holidays)

evidence.note: Business rule claim - validated with relaxed threshold

claim_ui_checks.claim: System supports both calendar days (30) and working days (22) leave policies

checks.name: semantic_leave_policy_flexibility
checks.claim_text: System supports both calendar days (30) and working days (22) leave policies
checks.validation_hint: Test daily pay calculation with both calendar and working day configurations

claim_ui_checks.claim: User can access Daily Wage Calculator via Settings → Payroll → Daily Wage Calculation

checks.name: semantic_navigation_path
checks.claim_text: User can access Daily Wage Calculator via Settings → Payroll → Daily Wage Calculation
checks.validation_hint: Verify navigation path exists and leads to correct page

claim_ui_checks.claim: User can select between calendar days, working days, and custom days

checks.name: semantic_calculation_base_selection
checks.claim_text: User can select between calendar days, working days, and custom days
checks.validation_hint: Check that all three calculation base options are available

claim_ui_checks.claim: User can choose salary components: basic salary, basic salary plus allowances, or allowances only

checks.name: semantic_salary_component_selection
checks.claim_text: User can choose salary components: basic salary, basic salary plus allowances, or allowances only
checks.validation_hint: Verify all three salary component options can be selected

claim_ui_checks.claim: Super admin can navigate to Daily wage calculation via Settings > Payroll

checks.name: semantic_navigation_path_001
checks.claim_text: Super admin can navigate to Daily wage calculation via Settings > Payroll

claim_ui_checks.claim: Supports three calculation bases: custom days, calendar days, working days

checks.name: semantic_calculation_basis_001
checks.claim_text: Supports three calculation bases: custom days, calendar days, working days
checks.validation_hint: Verify all three calculation methods are available and functional

evidence.note: Business rule claim - validated with relaxed threshold

claim_ui_checks.claim: Changes to proration settings immediately affect all active (unpaid) payroll amounts

checks.name: semantic_system_behavior_001
checks.claim_text: Changes to proration settings immediately affect all active (unpaid) payroll amounts
checks.validation_hint: Test impact of proration setting changes on payroll calculations

claim_ui_checks.claim: The daily wage calculator in payroll settings intentionally overrides the formula configured in leave policy for unpaid leave. The leave policy formula appears greyed out, indicating it is not active. This creates user confusion about which formula is actually being applied for daily wage calculations.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_formula_override
checks.claim_text: The daily wage calculator in payroll settings intentionally overrides the formula configured in leave policy for unpaid leave. The leave policy formula appears greyed out, indicating it is not active. This creates user confusion about which formula is actually being applied for daily wage calculations.

claim_ui_checks.claim: System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were incorrectly based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in payroll calculation discrepancies.

checks.name: semantic_unpaid_leave_deduction_calculation
checks.claim_text: System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were incorrectly based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in payroll calculation discrepancies.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system incorrectly calculates service days by using 365 days instead of 366 days for 2024, resulting in an inaccurate gratuity amount. When calculating End of Service (EOS) gratuity, the system fails to recognize 2024 as a leap year, causing a calculation discrepancy of approximately AED 17.26.

checks.name: semantic_leap_year_calculation_error
checks.claim_text: The system incorrectly calculates service days by using 365 days instead of 366 days for 2024, resulting in an inaccurate gratuity amount. When calculating End of Service (EOS) gratuity, the system fails to recognize 2024 as a leap year, causing a calculation discrepancy of approximately AED 17.26.

claim_ui_checks.claim: End of Service (EOS) calculation is producing incorrect pro-rated amounts due to a rounding or decimal precision error. The daily wage formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but when calculating pro-rated EOS amounts, the system consistently shows amounts that are less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals.

checks.name: semantic_eos_calculation_decimal_precision
checks.claim_text: End of Service (EOS) calculation is producing incorrect pro-rated amounts due to a rounding or decimal precision error. The daily wage formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but when calculating pro-rated EOS amounts, the system consistently shows amounts that are less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The daily wage calculator's gratuity calculation involves complex logic for handling partial years of service, especially for periods above 5 years. The system uses different calculation approaches for complete and incomplete years, including specific handling for leap years by using 366 as a divisor when appropriate.

checks.name: semantic_gratuity_calculation_complexity
checks.claim_text: The daily wage calculator's gratuity calculation involves complex logic for handling partial years of service, especially for periods above 5 years. The system uses different calculation approaches for complete and incomplete years, including specific handling for leap years by using 366 as a divisor when appropriate.

claim_ui_checks.claim: System may not consistently account for February 29th when calculating service duration for gratuity, potentially causing minor discrepancies in total days worked (912 vs 913 days)

checks.name: semantic_leap_year_day_calculation
checks.claim_text: System may not consistently account for February 29th when calculating service duration for gratuity, potentially causing minor discrepancies in total days worked (912 vs 913 days)

claim_ui_checks.claim: Platform calculates days worked with a potential extra day (622 vs 623 days), causing slight variations in gratuity calculation. The system uses a fixed divisor of 30 days for daily wage, which may not align with all client calculation preferences.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_calculation_discrepancy
checks.claim_text: Platform calculates days worked with a potential extra day (622 vs 623 days), causing slight variations in gratuity calculation. The system uses a fixed divisor of 30 days for daily wage, which may not align with all client calculation preferences.

claim_ui_checks.claim: System calculates leave salary based on predefined policy configuration, which may not align with user expectations about calendar days. The daily wage is divided by a configured number of days (30 vs 31), potentially causing salary calculation differences.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_divisor_configuration
checks.claim_text: System calculates leave salary based on predefined policy configuration, which may not align with user expectations about calendar days. The daily wage is divided by a configured number of days (30 vs 31), potentially causing salary calculation differences.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The daily wage calculator's 'working days' setting causes monthly fluctuations in leave salary accrual calculations. The daily wage rate changes based on the number of working days in each month, leading to inconsistent cumulative totals.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_calculation_variation
checks.claim_text: The daily wage calculator's 'working days' setting causes monthly fluctuations in leave salary accrual calculations. The daily wage rate changes based on the number of working days in each month, leading to inconsistent cumulative totals.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system calculates leave salary and salary proration using different daily wage divisors (30 vs 30.42 days), causing calculation discrepancies. Leave salary uses a 30-day divisor while salary proration uses 30.42 days, leading to different prorated amounts.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_divisor_mismatch
checks.claim_text: The system calculates leave salary and salary proration using different daily wage divisors (30 vs 30.42 days), causing calculation discrepancies. Leave salary uses a 30-day divisor while salary proration uses 30.42 days, leading to different prorated amounts.

claim_ui_checks.claim: User initially misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

checks.name: semantic_working_days_calculation_misunderstanding
checks.claim_text: User initially misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system fails to correctly prorate salaries when an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing date. When an employee is offboarded (e.g., on Nov 28th) and payroll is processed earlier (e.g., Nov 27th), the system displays the full monthly salary instead of a prorated amount.

checks.name: semantic_salary_proration_calculation_logic
checks.claim_text: The system fails to correctly prorate salaries when an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing date. When an employee is offboarded (e.g., on Nov 28th) and payroll is processed earlier (e.g., Nov 27th), the system displays the full monthly salary instead of a prorated amount.

claim_ui_checks.claim: When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Moving the leave request back to pending/accepted does not resolve the issue. Even after deleting the unpaid leave request entirely, the unpaid leave deduction persists in payroll deductions.

checks.name: semantic_unpaid_leave_deduction_sync
checks.claim_text: When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Moving the leave request back to pending/accepted does not resolve the issue. Even after deleting the unpaid leave request entirely, the unpaid leave deduction persists in payroll deductions.

claim_ui_checks.claim: When public holidays are added after a leave request is created, the daily wage calculation becomes inconsistent between Payroll and Time Off modules. This causes incorrect salary deduction amounts that cannot be retroactively corrected.

checks.name: semantic_public_holiday_timing_calculation
checks.claim_text: When public holidays are added after a leave request is created, the daily wage calculation becomes inconsistent between Payroll and Time Off modules. This causes incorrect salary deduction amounts that cannot be retroactively corrected.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The platform currently displays incorrect remarks for daily wage calculations in February, showing 31 days instead of the actual 29 days for leap years. While the backend calculation remains accurate, the frontend display creates potential user confusion.

checks.name: semantic_remark_display_mismatch
checks.claim_text: The platform currently displays incorrect remarks for daily wage calculations in February, showing 31 days instead of the actual 29 days for leap years. While the backend calculation remains accurate, the frontend display creates potential user confusion.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system applies a global daily rate configuration that overrides individual leave policy settings for unpaid leave calculations. This means the daily wage is calculated using a system-wide setting instead of policy-specific methods, potentially leading to incorrect salary deductions.

checks.name: semantic_unpaid_leave_calculation_override
checks.claim_text: The system applies a global daily rate configuration that overrides individual leave policy settings for unpaid leave calculations. This means the daily wage is calculated using a system-wide setting instead of policy-specific methods, potentially leading to incorrect salary deductions.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system shows the daily rate from the payroll month (May) instead of the leave occurrence month (April), causing user confusion. The actual deduction amount is calculated correctly, but the displayed daily rate does not match the month when leave occurred.

checks.name: semantic_daily_rate_display_mismatch
checks.claim_text: The system shows the daily rate from the payroll month (May) instead of the leave occurrence month (April), causing user confusion. The actual deduction amount is calculated correctly, but the displayed daily rate does not match the month when leave occurred.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The current Bayzat payroll system lacks automated salary calculation based on precise working days. The platform cannot dynamically adjust salaries proportionally when employees work more or fewer than the standard 26 working days.

checks.name: semantic_payroll_calculation_automation
checks.claim_text: The current Bayzat payroll system lacks automated salary calculation based on precise working days. The platform cannot dynamically adjust salaries proportionally when employees work more or fewer than the standard 26 working days.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Payroll daily wage calculator configuration overrides leave policy formula for unpaid leave calculations. The leave policy formula becomes inactive and is displayed as greyed out.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_formula_precedence
checks.claim_text: Payroll daily wage calculator configuration overrides leave policy formula for unpaid leave calculations. The leave policy formula becomes inactive and is displayed as greyed out.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Unpaid leave deductions may not automatically update if salary configuration changes after leave request creation

checks.name: semantic_salary_configuration_update_timing
checks.claim_text: Unpaid leave deductions may not automatically update if salary configuration changes after leave request creation

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system defaults to 365 days per year, failing to correctly account for leap years when calculating total service days for gratuity computation.

checks.name: semantic_leap_year_service_day_calculation
checks.claim_text: The system defaults to 365 days per year, failing to correctly account for leap years when calculating total service days for gratuity computation.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Pro-rated amounts are calculated using (basic + allowances / 30), but suffer from decimal precision errors that consistently underreport amounts.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_calculation_precision
checks.claim_text: Pro-rated amounts are calculated using (basic + allowances / 30), but suffer from decimal precision errors that consistently underreport amounts.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Leave days are accrued at end of month, preventing inclusion of partial month leave in End of Service (EOS) calculations

checks.name: semantic_leave_accrual_monthly_policy
checks.claim_text: Leave days are accrued at end of month, preventing inclusion of partial month leave in End of Service (EOS) calculations

claim_ui_checks.claim: Unclear methodology for counting service days, including departure date and leap year days

checks.name: semantic_gratuity_calculation_methodology
checks.claim_text: Unclear methodology for counting service days, including departure date and leap year days

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system calculates service duration with nuanced rules, including different approaches for years before and after 5 years of service, and specific handling of partial years.

checks.name: semantic_calculation_methodology_complexity
checks.claim_text: The system calculates service duration with nuanced rules, including different approaches for years before and after 5 years of service, and specific handling of partial years.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Daily wage is calculated using a hardcoded divisor of 30 days (Basic/30), which cannot be modified or configured to alternative formulas like (Basic × 12/365)

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_calculation_method
checks.claim_text: Daily wage is calculated using a hardcoded divisor of 30 days (Basic/30), which cannot be modified or configured to alternative formulas like (Basic × 12/365)

claim_ui_checks.claim: The platform cannot override the standard leave salary calculation method based on policy configurations. Users are bound by the predefined divisor settings for daily wage calculations.

checks.name: semantic_leave_salary_calculation_rigidity
checks.claim_text: The platform cannot override the standard leave salary calculation method based on policy configurations. Users are bound by the predefined divisor settings for daily wage calculations.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Leave salary accrual is calculated based on working days, which varies month to month

checks.name: semantic_working_days_accrual_calculation
checks.claim_text: Leave salary accrual is calculated based on working days, which varies month to month

claim_ui_checks.claim: The platform calculates leave salary and salary proration using separate configurations that cannot be automatically aligned without manual intervention.

checks.name: semantic_independent_daily_wage_configurations
checks.claim_text: The platform calculates leave salary and salary proration using separate configurations that cannot be automatically aligned without manual intervention.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Salary proration is calculated based on the specific work week configuration, which may include all 7 days as working days

checks.name: semantic_work_week_proration_logic
checks.claim_text: Salary proration is calculated based on the specific work week configuration, which may include all 7 days as working days

claim_ui_checks.claim: Salary proration only works correctly when departure date is in the past, not when it's in the future

checks.name: semantic_proration_date_sensitivity
checks.claim_text: Salary proration only works correctly when departure date is in the past, not when it's in the future

claim_ui_checks.claim: Leave management system does not reliably sync deduction changes with payroll module when leave transactions are modified, deleted, or status is changed.

checks.name: semantic_leave_payroll_sync_limitation
checks.claim_text: Leave management system does not reliably sync deduction changes with payroll module when leave transactions are modified, deleted, or status is changed.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Daily wage is calculated as: (basic salary + allowance) / working days, where working days exclude weekends and public holidays

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_calculation_constraints
checks.claim_text: Daily wage is calculated as: (basic salary + allowance) / working days, where working days exclude weekends and public holidays

claim_ui_checks.claim: Time Off module cannot send complete leave request details to Payroll module in real-time, causing calculation inconsistencies

checks.name: semantic_module_synchronization_limitation
checks.claim_text: Time Off module cannot send complete leave request details to Payroll module in real-time, causing calculation inconsistencies

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system may default to 31 days when calculating daily rates for February, instead of using the correct 29 days in leap years.

checks.name: semantic_leap_year_calculation
checks.claim_text: The system may default to 31 days when calculating daily rates for February, instead of using the correct 29 days in leap years.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The platform has a global configuration that supersedes individual policy-level settings for unpaid leave calculations

checks.name: semantic_global_configuration_precedence
checks.claim_text: The platform has a global configuration that supersedes individual policy-level settings for unpaid leave calculations

Failed paths indicate potential documentation updates needed, NOT system errors. Conceptual process flows (business workflows) are identified using procedures context and are NOT treated as clickable menu paths.
